bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to A.W. Ide, April 18, 1940

div1.p: Hench provides information about resorts in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to A.W. Ide, April 18, 1940
div1.opener:
April 18, 1940
Dr. A. W. Ide
1515 Charles Street
St. Paul, Minnesota
My dear Doctor Ide:
div1.p:
I promised to get some information for you regarding other likely resorts in
Cuba.

I know of no hotels in Havana which I could recommend particularly for a long
visit. Of course the Nacional Hotel is the best. It has the disadvantage of being almost
two or three miles from down down and you have a fifty cent taxi ride every time your
wife might want to shop. It has its own pool and a beautiful location. We had a very
nice room with twin beds and bath for ten dollars a day, European plan. The meals are
expensive, and are all right but not sufficiently wonderful to make one forget the expense.
Breakfast is seventy-five cents to a dollar and a quarter, lunch or dinner a dollar and a
half to two dollars.

I found mixed opinions concerning the Sevilla-Biltmore. Thirteen years ago when
I visited Cuba first, it was the swank hotel, cost thirty dollars a day and was worth it.
Three years ago, my wife and I stayed there. It was about eight dollars a day, and its
main advantage was that it was in town. It was obviously run down. One Cuban friend told
us that it was now even worse than then, another told us it was now better than then.

The third hotel to be recommended is the Hotel Presidente. It is even further out
than the Nacional, being about a half mile further from town. It is a very nice hotel,
a little less expensive than the Nacional but not so pretentious. There are many Cuban
hotels and should you at any time wish to write my frind, Mr. John J. Moran, of 455,
Avenida Menocal, I am sure that he might give you some dope. Incidentally, Mr. Moran is
the John J. Moran who was one of the first two to volunteer to Walter Reed for experimental
yellow fever. It was Mr. Moran whose part was taken by Robert Montgomery in the movie
“Yellow Jack”.

I have heard from time to time much favorable comment concerning Cuba's famous
beach, Veradero Beach. It is about a hundred miles from Havana, and is really a sort of
a rustic Atlantic City, apparently mostly a one-street affair, with small hotels facing
the occean, one or two swanky clubs, and I think a movie or so, which is about all; but
the beach is said to be wonderful and the water marvelous. I would like to try it sometime.
Note the enclosures and the writeup. Another place at Varadero Beach is the Kawama Beach
Club, run by Colonel Silva. I think this is a sort of a semi-private beach club, meaning
that you can't go down there and get a room, but if you write ahead of time and go through
the motions of an introduction, which I gather can be easily done, you would be admitted
there. It might be a little nicer than the hotel.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
